oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Seed-bank dynamics of native and invasive Impatiens species during a five-year field experiment under various environmental conditions
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Skálová, Hana
Moravcová, Lenka
Čuda, Jan
Pyšek, Petr
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: field experiment
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Despite recent evidence on the important role of seed banks associated with plant invasions, and a large body of literature on invasive annual <jats:italic>Impatiens</jats:italic> species, little is known about the seed bank characteristics of <jats:italic>Impatiens</jats:italic> species. To bridge this gap, we conducted a five-year field experiment where we buried seeds of two invasive species (<jats:italic>I. glandulifera</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>I. parviflora</jats:italic>) and one native species (<jats:italic>I. noli-tangere</jats:italic>) across four localities in the Czech Republic, harbouring all three <jats:italic>Impatiens</jats:italic> species and differing in the environmental conditions. We found that the three <jats:italic>Impatiens</jats:italic> species differed in the characteristics of their seed banks. Both invasive species had a high seed germination rate of almost 100% in the first year after seed burial, while <50% of seeds of the native <jats:italic>I. noli-tangere</jats:italic> germinated during this year. In <jats:italic>I. parviflora</jats:italic> all seeds germinated in the first year after seed burial and later decomposed, i.e. the species had a transient seed bank. For <jats:italic>I. glandulifera</jats:italic>, the most invasive species, the survival of seeds differed among localities. At the first and second localities, the seeds decomposed in the first year after seed burial; in the third locality the seeds germinated in the second year; and in the fourth one, the seeds still germinated in the fourth year. The native <jats:italic>I. noli-tangere</jats:italic> formed a short-term persistent seed bank across all localities. Germinating or dormant seeds were found in the third year after burial in all localities, and in one locality the seeds persisted until the fifth year. The germination and dormancy in <jats:italic>I. noli-tangere</jats:italic> were constrained by low minimum temperatures during winter. In addition, germination was highest at intermediate soil moisture, and the most dormant seeds were recorded in soils with intermediate nitrogen concentration. The germination of <jats:italic>I. glandulifera</jats:italic> was slightly limited by low soil nitrogen. However, no such effect was found in <jats:italic>I. parviflora</jats:italic>. We suggest that in the invasive <jats:italic>Impatiens</jats:italic> species seed resistance to environmental factors and high germination at least partly explain their wide distribution.</jats:p>
